Description: On June 1, 2015, the U.S. Department of Energy's (DOE) Office of Enforcement issued a Consent Order (NCO-2015-02) to Bechtel National, Inc., the management and operating contractor for DOE's Waste Treatment and Immobilization Plant (WTP), for deficiencies in nuclear safety associated with misalignment between design documents and facility authorization bases; welds in vessels fabricated for and accepted at the plant; and implementation of WTP quality assurance and corrective action management programs. The contractor agreed to the Consent Order.

On September 13, 2010, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Health, Safety and Security's Office of Enforcement issued a Consent Order to Bechtel National, Inc. for deficiencies in commercial grade dedication processes for vendors supplying materials and components for construction of the at the Hanford Waste Treatment and Immobilization Plant. The contractor agreed to the Consent Order.

On May 31, 2012, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Health, Safety and Security's Office of Enforcement and Oversight issued a Preliminary Notice of Violation (WEA-2012-02) to Bechtel National, Incorporated for violations of 10 C.F.R. 851 associated with a July 16, 2010, foot injury to a millwright and a March 16, 2011, formwork panel rigging event that occurred at DOE's Hanford Waste Treatment and Immobilization Plat (WTP).

Description: On July 28, 2005, the U.S. Department of Energy issued a Consent Order to Bechtel Hanford, Inc. associated with two events that resulted in significant personnel uptakes to two individuals in December 2004 at the 618-2 Burial Ground at DOE's Hanford site. The contractor agreed to the Consent Order.

Company: Bechtel Infrastructure Corp. and PB Americas Inc
Description: A joint venture between Bechtel Infrastructure Corp. and PB Americas Inc., known as B/PB, and certain design consultants agreed to pay the United States and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts a total of $458 million to settle allegations that B/PB violated federal and state criminal and civil laws by failing to provide adequate construction management and quality assurance services to the Central Artery Tunnel, known as the Big Dig, in Boston and that the design consultants caused excess costs to be incurred on the project.

On July 16, 2010, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Health, Safety and Security's Office of Enforcement issued a Preliminary Notice of Violation to Bechtel Jacobs Company, LLC for violations of 10 C.F.R. 851 that were associated with a March 19, 2009, electrical arc incident in building K-1210 at DOE's East Tennessee Technology Park. Penalty took the form of a contract fee reduction.

On July 16, 2010, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Health, Safety and Security's Office of Enforcement issued a Preliminary Notice of Violation to Bechtel Jacobs Company, LLC for violations of 10 C.F.R. 824 associated with the theft of classified matter from DOE's East Tennessee Technology Park (ETTP) in October 2009.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Bechtel and URS agreed to pay a total of $125 million to resolve allegations that in the design and on-going construction of the U.S. Department of Energy's Waste Treatment & Immobilization Plant project in Hanford, Washington they falsely represented and charged DOE for deficient goods and services, which failed to be of the highest quality for nuclear facilities.

Private Litigation Case Title: Kanawi et al v. Bechtel Corporation et al

Description: Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million, with the remainder to be paid by the consultants.
Notes: Company names and share of settlement paid are taken from documents attached to press release.

Description: Bechtel National Inc., Bechtel Corporation, AECOM Energy & Construction, Inc., and their subsidiary Waste Treatment Completion Company LLC, agreed to pay $57,750,000 to the U.S. Department of Justice to resolve claims that Bechtel and AECOM fraudulently overcharged the U.S. Department of Energy in connection with its operation of the Hanford Waste Treatment Plant project. The False Claims Act claims arose from allegations that Bechtel and AECOM management were aware of and failed to prevent inflated labor hours being charged to DOE, and for falsely billing DOE for work not actually performed. The settlement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here half of the total is attributed to each firm.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Four companies which received contracts from FEMA to provide trailers to residents of Louisiana displaced by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita agreed to pay a total of $5 million to resolve multi-district litigation alleging that the trailers contained harmful formaldehyde. The parties did not disclose how much each of the companies was to pay. Here we assume the total was divided evenly among them.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: FEMA Trailer Formaldehyde Products Liability Litigation

Company: BECHTEL OIL, GAS & CHEMICALS CONSTRUCTION SERVICES, INC.
